etymology.description: Depicts the head of a nail -> 丁
etymology.interpretation: The character 丁 originally depicted the head of a nail, emphasizing simplicity and directness. While it has developed other interpretations over time, such as a head or city wall, these relate to similar shapes and functions. Today, 釘(釘) (dīng, 'nail') reflects this meaning.

examples.chinese: 工人熟练地把丁敲进了墙壁(工人熟練地把丁敲進了牆壁)。
examples.pinyin: Gōngrén shúliàn de bǎ dīng qiāng jìnle qiángbì.
examples.english: The worker skillfully hammered the nail into the wall.

examples.chinese: 他精心挑选了铁质丁(他精心挑選了鐵質丁)，确保家具稳固(確保傢俱穩固)。
examples.pinyin: Tā jīngxīn tiāoxuǎnle tiě zhì dīng, quèbǎo jiājù wěngù.
examples.english: He carefully selected the iron nail to ensure the furniture was stable.

examples.chinese: 请把散落的丁收好(請把散落的丁收好)。
examples.pinyin: Qǐng bǎ sànluò de dīng shōuhǎo.
